@flamingbear environment.yml is like requirements.txt and allows you a way to install all of the requirements you may need including pip ones.

However, if you want packages, you need to create packages for all of your python requirements. There are helper tools though like conda skeleton pypi, which constructs a recipe for a package on PyPI. Using the --recursive option, you can get recipes for all dependencies, as well.
text:
@flamingbear `environment.yml` is like `requirements.txt` and allows you a way to install all of the requirements you may need including `pip` ones.

However, if you want packages, you need to create packages for all of your python requirements. There are helper tools though like `conda skeleton pypi`, which constructs a recipe for a package on PyPI. Using the `--recursive` option, you can get recipes for all dependencies, as well.

html:
Hi Everybody,
I’m banging my head against conda features and I’m not sure what the best path forward is.
The short is as follow:
We use vtk. We have two option for Linux when building vtk with or without mesalib.
Mesalib is already in conda-forge (thanks) and has the “mesalib” track_feature on.
Now I don’t understand how to tell the recipe to build both possible version the “regular” one and the one with the mesalib option.
I see numpy provide the openblas feature and you go back to a regular numpy if you yank openblas.
I would like my users to be able to choose if they want this feature or not.
The problem propagates further as we have many package which are pure python that rely on the “vtk” package, for these, the code is identical they do not care, so I’m assuming we could just add “Vtk” as a requirement correct?
Ideally I would like the default to come w/o the measlib feature and if the user decides to install mesalib then have automatically vtk being updated to the vtk-mesalib feature enabled.
Thanks for any pointers
text:
Hi Everybody,
I’m banging my head against conda features and I’m not sure what the best path forward is.
The short is as follow:
We use vtk. We have two option for Linux when building vtk with or without mesalib.
Mesalib is already in conda-forge (thanks) and has the “mesalib” track_feature on.
Now I don’t understand how to tell the recipe to build both possible version the “regular” one and the one with the mesalib option.
I see numpy provide the openblas feature and you go back to a regular numpy if you yank openblas.
I would like my users to be able to choose if they want this feature or not.
The problem propagates further as we have many package which are pure python that rely on the “vtk” package, for these, the code is identical they do not care, so I’m assuming we could just add “Vtk” as a requirement correct?
Ideally I would like the default to come w/o the measlib feature and if the user decides to install mesalib then have automatically vtk being updated to the vtk-mesalib feature enabled.
Thanks for any pointers

{% set data = load_setup_py_data() %}

Yup, this is what was confusing to me!

It is my understanding that using something like {{ cdt('libxrender-devel') }}creates a folder librsvg_XXXX/_build_env/x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu/sysroot/user/lib64 with the required libraries. However, the folder that gets appended to LDFLAGS, etc. is librsvg_XXXX/_h_env_placehold_placehold..../lib, which does not contain any of the libraries in x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu/sysroot/user/lib64.

Maybe a better example of this is the second build which I am having trouble with: gobject (https://gitlab.com/ostrokach-forge/pygobject/-/jobs/53546289). Sorry for the messy build log; I've been trying to debug this by tweaking things for the entire day. Basically, I added {{ cdt('libxrender-devel') }} to the build: section of the conda recipe, but the build still fails with /opt/conda/conda-bld/pygobject_1519170951873/work/tests/tmp-introspecto5husdqr/.libs/lt-Regress-1.0: error while loading shared libraries: libXrender.so.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory.

If I use xorg-libxrender from the conda-forge channel, the build correctly finds the libXrender.so.1 library with no further modifications.
text:
Yup, this is what was confusing to me!

It is my understanding that using something like `{{ cdt('libxrender-devel') }}`creates a folder `librsvg_XXXX/_build_env/x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu/sysroot/user/lib64` with the required libraries. However, the folder that gets appended to LDFLAGS, etc. is `librsvg_XXXX/_h_env_placehold_placehold..../lib`, which does not contain any of the libraries in `x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu/sysroot/user/lib64`.

Maybe a better example of this is the second build which I am having trouble with: `gobject` (https://gitlab.com/ostrokach-forge/pygobject/-/jobs/53546289).  Sorry for the messy build log; I've been trying to debug this by tweaking things for the entire day. Basically, I added `{{ cdt('libxrender-devel') }}` to the `build:` section of the conda recipe, but the build still fails with `/opt/conda/conda-bld/pygobject_1519170951873/work/tests/tmp-introspecto5husdqr/.libs/lt-Regress-1.0: error while loading shared libraries: libXrender.so.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory`. 

If I use `xorg-libxrender` from the conda-forge channel, the build correctly finds the `libXrender.so.1` library with no further modifications.

html: my understanding (which is not great; @mingwandroid is the one who understands this better) is that the compiler's internal paths should point to that x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu/sysroot/user/lib64 folder (also known as a sysroot). You should not need any recipe modification. I hope that Ray can help clarify what's going wrong here.

html: I see. Yes, if you have inter-dependent builds, you can't use --croot without also managing your artifact availability somehow. It should be reasonable to modify https://github.com/conda/conda-build/blob/717d04ae8ae65ab73b7eb8fedd0d37a84cad69a5/conda_build/build.py#L2300 to filter the folder list based on the current lock list. Locks are located in <PREFIX>/locks, and the lock name is the base64 encoded path: https://github.com/conda/conda-build/blob/master/conda_build/utils.py#L550

html: Does CMake really need to know which conda pkg provides which library? Provided it’s installed (requirements:host) in $PREFIX, often CMake’s own detection mechanisms find the libraries, and if not, you can provide it hints (e.g., HDF5_LIBRARIES=$PREFIX/lib/libhdf5.so or PROJECT_DIR=$PREFIX/share/cmake/PROJECT)

build:
  skip: True  # [win and vc > 9]

text:
@dharhas you need to do something like:

```
build:
  skip: True  # [win and vc > 9]
  ignore_run_exports:
    - vc

requirements:
  build:
    - {{ compiler('c') }}
  run:
    - vs2008_runtime   # [win]
```

html: there are several parts there.
text: there are several parts there.

html: first, you only build on vc9
text: first, you only build on vc9

html: next, you want to bypass the vc package as a run_export, because it is what enforces mutual exclusivity and prevents you from using it with py3
text: next, you want to bypass the vc package as a run_export, because it is what enforces mutual exclusivity and prevents you from using it with py3

html: note that you are mixing runtimes, which is not advisable
text: note that you are mixing runtimes, which is not advisable

html: finally, the compiler stuff stays the same, but you manually add the runtime requirement that would otherwise be provided by the vc provided by run_exports
text: finally, the compiler stuff stays the same, but you manually add the runtime requirement that would otherwise be provided by the vc provided by run_exports

html: I'm working on a package that depends on boost and needs to be compiled with the c++11 standard libraries.  However, it looks like primary boost libraries packaged in conda were not build with c++11 support. Is there another boost package that has c++11 support?
text: I'm working on a package that depends on boost and needs to be compiled with the c++11 standard libraries.  However, it looks like primary boost libraries packaged in conda were not build with c++11 support. Is there another boost package that has c++11 support?

html:
@swainn you might be getting conda-forge packages confused with the Anaconda packages. All of Anaconda's packages are built with very new compilers and have C++11 support, as well as 14 and some 17. More details at https://www.anaconda.com/blog/developer-blog/utilizing-the-new-compilers-in-anaconda-distribution-5/?lang=en-us

You must be sure that your boost packages are coming from repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main, aka defaults.
text:

More details at https://www.anaconda.com/blog/developer-blog/utilizing-the-new-compilers-in-anaconda-distribution-5/?lang=en-us

You must be sure that your boost packages are coming from repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main, aka defaults.

html:
@msarahan, I have a couple of quick questions regarding the API:
  • Is it fine to use a single conda_build.config.Config instance while batch-processing/-rendering recipes? Or does it get modified while rendering such that it is best to use a new instance for each recipe?
  • Would you accept a PR to extend either the --exclusive-config-file CLI parameter or the conda_build: config_file .condarc parameter to accept multiple paths?
    The use case is Bioconda which is essentially a conda-forge downstream repository now. As such we want to use conda-forge-pinning's conda_build_config.yaml but also add our own on top of that. Using --variant-files won't work, due to the config file processing order, as soon as we would start to add per-recipe configuration files.
  • I noticed that exclusive_config_file and conda_build: config_file/~/conda_build_config.yaml are parsed over and over again in batch-processing recipes (for every call of variants.get_package_variants). Would it be possible to cache their parsed contents somewhere? I think caching that should be fine since it's the "bottom configuration" and doesn't depend on anything in the recipe, right?
text:
@msarahan, I have a couple of quick questions regarding the API:
- Is it fine to use a single `conda_build.config.Config` instance while batch-processing/-rendering recipes? Or does it get modified while rendering such that it is best to use a new instance for each recipe?
- Would you accept a PR to extend either the `--exclusive-config-file` CLI parameter or the `conda_build: config_file` `.condarc` parameter to accept multiple paths?
  The use case is Bioconda which is essentially a conda-forge downstream repository now. As such we want to use `conda-forge-pinning`'s `conda_build_config.yaml` but also add our own on top of that. Using `--variant-files` won't  work, due to the config file processing order, as soon as we would start to add per-recipe configuration files.
- I noticed that `exclusive_config_file` and `conda_build: config_file`/`~/conda_build_config.yaml` are parsed over and over again in batch-processing recipes (for every call of `variants.get_package_variants`). Would it be possible to cache their parsed contents somewhere? I think caching that should be fine since it's the "bottom configuration" and doesn't depend on anything in the recipe, right?

Conda takes a pretty long while to figure out the dependencies

most time by far is spent on installing the packages in temporary envs

So, is it the dependency resolution or the installation itself (i.e., the part where the log outputs "Preparing/Verifying/Executing transaction") that is taking the most time? If it's the latter, you could just use a faster storage temporarily, if you have one available (e.g., using CONDA_BLD_PATH/CONDA_PKGS_DIRS and the like). I don't think there is (or at least am not aware of) a way to reuse a build environment in the way you asked for. If you don't build often, but rather just test your Python package itself often, I'd advice to manually create an environment with the dependencies and then pip install --no-deps -e .(.=assuming your setup.py is in the CWD) your package into that environment.

@msarahan, while you're here, what are your thoughts on the following (short "yes"/"no"/"yes, make PR for X" answers suffice):

@msarahan, I have a couple of quick questions regarding the API:

  • Is it fine to use a single conda_build.config.Config instance while batch-processing/-rendering recipes? Or does it get modified while rendering such that it is best to use a new instance for each recipe?
  • Would you accept a PR to extend either the --exclusive-config-file CLI parameter or the conda_build: config_file .condarc parameter to accept multiple paths?
    The use case is Bioconda which is essentially a conda-forge downstream repository now. As such we want to use conda-forge-pinning's conda_build_config.yaml but also add our own on top of that. Using --variant-files won't work, due to the config file processing order, as soon as we would start to add per-recipe configuration files.
  • I noticed that exclusive_config_file and conda_build: config_file/~/conda_build_config.yaml are parsed over and over again in batch-processing recipes (for every call of variants.get_package_variants). Would it be possible to cache their parsed contents somewhere? I think caching that should be fine since it's the "bottom configuration" and doesn't depend on anything in the recipe, right?
text:
@msarahan, while you're here, what are your thoughts on the following (short "yes"/"no"/"yes, make PR for X" answers suffice): 
> @msarahan, I have a couple of quick questions regarding the API:
- Is it fine to use a single `conda_build.config.Config` instance while batch-processing/-rendering recipes? Or does it get modified while rendering such that it is best to use a new instance for each recipe?
- Would you accept a PR to extend either the `--exclusive-config-file` CLI parameter or the `conda_build: config_file` `.condarc` parameter to accept multiple paths?
  The use case is Bioconda which is essentially a conda-forge downstream repository now. As such we want to use `conda-forge-pinning`'s `conda_build_config.yaml` but also add our own on top of that. Using `--variant-files` won't  work, due to the config file processing order, as soon as we would start to add per-recipe configuration files.
- I noticed that `exclusive_config_file` and `conda_build: config_file`/`~/conda_build_config.yaml` are parsed over and over again in batch-processing recipes (for every call of `variants.get_package_variants`). Would it be possible to cache their parsed contents somewhere? I think caching that should be fine since it's the "bottom configuration" and doesn't depend on anything in the recipe, right?

html:
@mbargull

Is it fine to use a single conda_build.config.Config instance while batch-processing/-rendering recipes? Or does it get modified while rendering such that it is best to use a new instance for each recipe?

It should be fine, but see this recent issue for maybe more info: https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes/pull/5935#issuecomment-392814567

Would you accept a PR to extend either the --exclusive-config-file CLI parameter or the conda_build: config_file .condarc parameter to accept multiple paths?
The use case is Bioconda which is essentially a conda-forge downstream repository now. As such we want to use conda-forge-pinning's conda_build_config.yaml but also add our own on top of that. Using --variant-files won't work, due to the config file processing order, as soon as we would start to add per-recipe configuration files.

Sure, I think that's fine. Just be really clear what the priority is. I think it would be most consistent to have later files have higher priority (this is backwards compared to channels in conda, but more consistent with the CLI behavior, and I hope consistent with the variant config files entry in condarc).

I noticed that exclusive_config_file and conda_build: config_file/~/conda_build_config.yaml are parsed over and over again in batch-processing recipes (for every call of variants.get_package_variants). Would it be possible to cache their parsed contents somewhere? I think caching that should be fine since it's the "bottom configuration" and doesn't depend on anything in the recipe, right?

What needs to be clarified here is what the scope of selectors is for any parsed config file. If you can use variables from the file itself as selectors, it needs to be iterative. If you can only use the small set of selectors that are hard-coded, then you can cache. Maybe I'm misunderstanding your question, though. I think if the assumption is "I'm doing batch processing and these files are always the same," then yes, I'd recommend caching it, perhaps by creating the Config instance and passing that around (copying it if you find it getting mutated undesirably)

html: PS: the .copy() method on a Config object should be helpful
text: PS: the .copy() method on a Config object should be helpful

html:
def copy(self):
    new = copy.copy(self)
    new.variant = copy.deepcopy(self.variant)
    if hasattr(self, 'variants'):
        new.variants = copy.deepcopy(self.variants)
    return new

Many thanks!

I think it would be most consistent to have later files have higher priority

Indeed, it would be conda-build -e lower-prio-config.yaml -e higher-prio-config.yaml

I think if the assumption is "I'm doing batch processing and these files are always the same,"

Correct, that's the case.

I'd recommend caching it, perhaps by creating the Config instance and passing that around (copying it if you find it getting mutated undesirably)

That's what I assumed previously to work, but conda_build.variants.get_package_variants calls conda_build.variants.find_config_files and for each of those files (which includes the exclusive_config_file) conda_build.variants.parse_config_file is called. Hence for different recipes get_package_variants does not load the parsed contents of exclusive_config_file from any cache.
I'm not too familiar with the code and thus wasn't sure where to add/find such caching.

PS: the .copy() method on a Config object should be helpful

Thanks for pointing it out, I missed that one!
text:
Many thanks!
> I think it would be most consistent to have later files have higher priority

Indeed, it would be `conda-build -e lower-prio-config.yaml -e higher-prio-config.yaml`

> I think if the assumption is "I'm doing batch processing and these files are always the same," 

Correct, that's the case.

>  I'd recommend caching it, perhaps by creating the Config instance and passing that around (copying it if you find it getting mutated undesirably)

That's what I assumed previously to work, but `conda_build.variants.get_package_variants` calls `conda_build.variants.find_config_files` and for each of those files (which includes the `exclusive_config_file`) `conda_build.variants.parse_config_file` is called. Hence for different recipes `get_package_variants` does not load the parsed contents of `exclusive_config_file` from any cache.
I'm not too familiar with the code and thus wasn't sure where to add/find such caching.

> PS: the .copy() method on a Config object should be helpful

Thanks for pointing it out, I missed that one!

Wise choice :wink:
I'd decouple the regular tests from the conda-build packaging in general and use the test section in meta.yaml just for fast-running sanity checks to see if the package was build successfully (e.g., tests for whether the application starts at all or is able to output help/version text, etc.). This is also the strategy for recipes in popular channels like conda-forge.

html: @TiemenSch we don't do anything to arbitrarily restrict builds. Conda-build actually does very little building. It really just creates environments, then runs your build script (bld.bat), and then bundles things up afterwards. For any significant build, whatever you're doing in bld.bat will dominate the total build time, and you need to investigate what in your script might be taking so long.

I created a recipe in build requirements with
```
    - {{ compiler('c') }}
    - {{ compiler('cxx') }}
```

However, when I compile that it is giving me a weird error in linking phase with an older package (openmqc). The error is:
``libopenmqc.so: undefined reference to `memcpy@GLIBC_2.14'``

If a put the build requirements as:
```
    - {{ compiler('c') }}
    - {{ compiler('cxx') }}
    - toolchain
```
It will use the compiler of my machine (gcc 7.3)and the problem is solved... I also tried in another machine with gcc 7.2 and the error does not appear

html:
The compiler packages from Anaconda vendor glibc 2.12. This is extremely helpful to in regards to ensuring compatibility/minimum requirements for all builds compiled with those compilers. glibc 2.12 is chosen since that's the one shipped with CentOS 6, the base system requirement targeted by Ananconda.
The error you got means that the libopenmqc.so that gets used was built with a newer glibc version. It would be best to rebuilt that library with those compilers.
Adding toolchain along the {{ compiler(...) }} packages essentially negates the use of the compilers and the effort to ensure glibc 2.12 is used: the built package might require a newer glibc than the one met by the minimum CentOS 6 requirement.
text:
The compiler packages from Anaconda vendor glibc 2.12. This is extremely helpful to in regards to ensuring compatibility/minimum requirements for all builds compiled with those compilers. glibc 2.12 is chosen since that's the one shipped with CentOS 6, the base system requirement targeted by Ananconda.
The error you got means that the `libopenmqc.so` that gets used was built with a newer glibc version. It would be best to rebuilt that library with those compilers.
Adding `toolchain` along the `{{ compiler(...) }}` packages essentially negates the use of the compilers and the effort to ensure glibc 2.12 is used: the built package might require a newer glibc than the one met by the minimum CentOS 6 requirement.

html: Ah, the log is very helpful! It shows g++ -c -O2 -DLINUX ... invocations which means the g++ on PATH is used. But the Anaconda compiler packages have their binaries explicitly named, e.g., like x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu-c++. Thus a g++ will not run those compilers. You should make sure the build process uses "${CC}"/"${CXX}" instead of hardcoded gcc/g++.
text: Ah, the log is very helpful! It shows `g++ -c -O2 -DLINUX  ...` invocations which means the `g++` on `PATH` is used. But the Anaconda compiler packages have their binaries explicitly named, e.g., like `x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu-c++`. Thus a `g++` will not run those compilers. You should make sure the build process uses `"${CC}"`/`"${CXX}"` instead of hardcoded `gcc`/`g++`.

I also looked into tox some more and it has great extension support from what I can see. I'm planning to spend some time to get tox-conda to life! That way, conda-build could focus on what it does best (building packages) and tox, too.

Especially for pure Python there could be significant overlap in build and test environments, but if all users do in build is python -m pip install . --no-deps, then they might as well use tox up front anyway. The overhead may reduce dramatically, if tox uses the same package cache. As much as I would like a one stop shop, packages should focus on one thing and do it well :).

html: Hopefully quick question on conda/windows builds.  I’m new to Windows, and need to use cython in a fall course I’m teaching to a mixed windows/macos cohort.  I’ve got a setup.py that calls cmake to build the cython extension — no problem in a Unix bash shell with the new anaconda compilers.  On windows however, I set my conda environment by launching an anaconda prompt, and a compiler environment by launching a developer command prompt for VS 2017.  Is there some way to merge these, or should I be doing something different?
text: Hopefully quick question on conda/windows builds.  I’m new to Windows, and need to use cython in a fall course I’m teaching to a mixed windows/macos cohort.  I’ve got a setup.py that calls cmake to build the cython extension — no problem in a Unix bash shell with the new anaconda compilers.  On windows however, I set my conda environment by launching an anaconda prompt, and a compiler environment by launching a developer command prompt for VS 2017.  Is there some way to merge these, or should I be doing something different?

html:
There is a vs2017 package that we haven't released yet, because of problems we've seen with vs2017 and some packages. Those problems may not affect you, though - they've been pretty detailed things in heavy C++, like Qt. https://anaconda.org/c3i_test2/vs2017_win-64

It's just activate scripts, not actual compilers. It'll replace your developer command prompt step. You will need one further customization, though. Conda-build defaults to vs2008 for python 2.7, and vs2015 for python 3.5+. The conda_build_config.yaml file can be used to change that default. The easiest thing to do is to copy the file from https://github.com/AnacondaRecipes/aggregate/blob/master/conda_build_config.yaml and change the c_compiler and cxx_compiler entries. Note that they are "zipped" with other keys. zipped fields must all have the same length, so don't delete entries arbitrarily.

html: Perhaps I didn't understand what you were doing.  conda_build_config.yaml is for conda-build.  If you do only steps 1 and 3, that should be fine for interactive use.  However, we don't use that workflow at all currently (we only use conda-build to produce packages), so you may hit some snags, such as runtime dependencies being missing.  It should be find on your students' computers, but if they try to ship their compiled stuff elsewhere, it may not work.  In that case, you'll want them to use conda-build to produce packages.  You'd remove your steps 1 and 3, write a conda recipe, and let conda-build take care of the compiler installation and environment activations.

html: Hi. I hope this is the right place to post this. I'm building a package with conda which uses cuda, and therefore nvcc for the build. As far as I can tell, this prevents me from using the anaconda distributed gcc/g++, as they are too new for nvcc. I'm currently building using a system gcc, but i'm worried about this leading to runtime linking different libraries (e.g., numpy links the conda libgcc and my program links the system libgcc). Whatever i'm doing currently seems to work, in that the code runs, but i'm worried about stability and subtle bugs. I wasn't able to find much guidance of this online or in the docs, and was wondering if anyone had any advice or could point me towards a resource to really nail down these issues. Thanks in advance!

html:
@stilley2 yes, correct. I see for you two options for reproducable environment:
1) Using Docker and system level compilers
2) Building your versions of compilers

if you decide following option 2, then your steps are following
1) check examples for certain versions of gcc, as here https://github.com/AnacondaRecipes/aggregate/blob/master/ctng-compilers-feedstock/recipe/conda_build_config.cos6.x86_64.gcc5.4.yaml
2) prepare your own config and use it as conda build -m <YOUR_CONFIG>
3) Use activation recipe with the same version of config

extra info for conda build config - here https://conda.io/docs/user-guide/tasks/build-packages/variants.html
for options on compilers https://crosstool-ng.github.io/ and some sample examples used in config: https://github.com/crosstool-ng/crosstool-ng/tree/master/samples

text:
If  I specify the following 
```
build:
    string:  abc_xyz
    number: 123
````
My expectation is to have the output file as `package_name-version-abc_xyz_123.tar.bz2`. 

However i end up with `package_name-version-abc_xyz.tar.bz2`even though the meta data files in the package correctly have 123 as the build number.   

If i skip setting the build string then i get the package with desired name format, but then the buildstring is one generated by conda and does not contain some custom information i want.. Is that desired feature or a bug ?

html: That's not a bug. Any value in build/string overrides all default behavior, including build number on the end. You can manually re-add it from the variables at https://conda.io/docs/user-guide/tasks/build-packages/environment-variables.html#environment-variables-set-during-the-build-process which you can use as jinja2 variables. See https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/conda.recipe/meta.yaml#L7-L8 for an example
text: That's not a bug.  Any value in build/string overrides all default behavior, including build number on the end.  You can manually re-add it from the variables at https://conda.io/docs/user-guide/tasks/build-packages/environment-variables.html#environment-variables-set-during-the-build-process which you can use as jinja2 variables.  See https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/conda.recipe/meta.yaml#L7-L8 for an example

@johnkit please refer to docs, specifically this TL;DR:

TL;DR: If you use the new {{ compiler() }} jinja2 to utilize our new compilers, you also must move anything that is not strictly a build tool into your host dependencies. This includes python, python libraries, and any shared libraries that you need to link against in your build. Examples of build tools include any {{ compiler() }}, make, autoconf, perl (for running scripts, not installing perl software), python (for running scripts, not for installing software).

html:
Hello Everyone
I'm building a conda package from a python program that makes use of pickled data files (ie. it relies on data files to work).
Is there a way to include these pickled data files in the conda package and make them accessible to the python code ?
text:
Hello Everyone
I'm building a conda package from a python program that makes use of pickled data files (ie. it relies on data files to work).
Is there a way to include these pickled data files in the conda package and make them accessible to the python code ?

html:
I found a workaround, but it's very convoluted...
In build.sh I copy my data files to a directory

mkdir -p $PREFIX/data/
cp data/quality/mydata.pickle $PREFIX/data/

And in my python code, I check with try/except if I'm executing the program from its directory, or from conda, and then retrieve the correct data location accordingly:

def get_mydata():
    try:
        ret = pickle.load(open("mydata.pickle", 'rb'))
        return(ret)
    except FileNotFoundError:
        cmd = "which mycondapackage"
        res = subprocess.check_output(cmd, shell=True)
        res = res.decode('utf-8').rstrip()
        path = "/".join(res.split("/")[:-2])+"/data/mydata.pickle "
        ret = pickle.load(open(path, 'rb'))
        return(ret)

As I said, very convoluted...
text:
I found a workaround, but it's very convoluted...
In `build.sh` I copy my data files to a directory
```
mkdir -p $PREFIX/data/
cp data/quality/mydata.pickle $PREFIX/data/
```

And in my python code, I check with try/except if I'm executing the program from its directory, or from conda, and then retrieve the correct data location accordingly:
```
def get_mydata():
    try:
        ret = pickle.load(open("mydata.pickle", 'rb'))
        return(ret)
    except FileNotFoundError:
        cmd = "which mycondapackage"
        res = subprocess.check_output(cmd, shell=True)
        res = res.decode('utf-8').rstrip()
        path = "/".join(res.split("/")[:-2])+"/data/mydata.pickle "
        ret = pickle.load(open(path, 'rb'))
        return(ret)
```

As I said, very convoluted...
